bibl.title: Answers to questions propounded by Jessie Daniel Ames, by Aristides Agramonte, May 27, 1930

div1.p: Agramonte answers Mrs. Ames' questions concerning her husband's actions and responsibilities with the yellow fever board in Cuba.

div1.head: Answers to questions propounded by Jessie Daniel Ames, by Aristides Agramonte, May 27, 1930

list.head: Anwers to questions propounded by Mrs. Jessie Daniel Ames.

item.p:
1. Were the care and observation of the Experimental Cases of Yellow
Fevor part of the regular duty of all Army Surgeons?

Certainly not. Dr. Roger P. Ames, Contract Surgeon, U.S. Army, had sole
medical charge of the experimental cases, because of his familiarity with,
and his supposed immunity to, yellow fever.

list.item:
2. Was Dr. Roger Post Ames assigned specially to the Experimental Camp?
Not to the experimental Camp Lazear, except in an administrative capacity.
He was assigned to care of the cases at a section of Columbia Barracks
Hospital, two miles from the experimental camp.

item.p:
3. What other surgeons were in charge of the Camp jointly with Dr. Roger
Post Ames?

If by “the Camp” is meant Camp Lazear, this was medically in charge of
the Board, Drs. Reed, Carroll, and Agramonte exclusively, and Dr. Ames only
attended to the administration of same. Dr. Ames took charge of cases
when removed from Camp Lazear to the Columbia Barracks Hospital section set
aside for them.

4. Were the numerous other members of the Medical Department who contracted
yellow fever, in hourly contact with yellow fever cases which were known to
be yellow fever cases?

If this question refers to the members of the Yellow-fever Board, YES.
If it is meant to allude to other surgeons of the Army, the question can
not be answered without the examination of records, not at hand.

5. Dr. Ames was in charge of the yellow fever Experimental Cases and in the
Camp when he contracted yellow fever. Was this the ordinary duty of all
surgeons in the Army or was it special duty undertaken to advance the
scientific esperiment to demonstrate the mosquito theory of the transmission
of yellow fever?

I do not know that the first part of the question is correct; as above
stated Ames was not “in charge” of Camp Lazear and when he took sick
there were no more experimental cases. It has been stated, (answer to
question #3,) that Dr. Ames had been specially assigned in attendance
upon the experimental cases, for the reasons mentioned. It was his duty
to accept the assignment and he performed it most worthily. The demon-
stration of mosquito transmission was terminated in each case, as soon as
the first symptom of yellow fever appeared, therefore, the treatment of
the disease in no way advanced “the scientific experiment” tending to
demonstrate mosquito infection.
